Yes, financial analysts use several other methods besides DCF and relative valuation to evaluate stocks. Some of them are:

1. Dividend Discount Model (DDM): The DDM values the stock based on the present value of future dividends that the company is expected to pay out. This approach is useful for mature companies that pay consistent dividends. 2. Price-to-Sales Ratio (P/S Ratio): Similar to the P/E ratio, the P/S ratio compares the stock price with the company's sales per share. It is often used for companies with negative earnings or with distorted earnings due to accounting practices. 3. Price-to-Cash Flow (P/CF Ratio): This metric compares the company's market capitalization to its operating cash flow. It is useful for assessing a company's ability to generate cash and pay debts in the short term. 4. Asset-based valuation: This approach values the company based on the value of its assets. This method is useful for companies with a significant amount of tangible assets, such as property or inventory. 5. Economic Value Added (EVA): This metric measures the difference between a company's net operating profit after tax and its cost of capital. It is useful for evaluating a company's overall profitability. Analysts may use a combination of these methods to gain a comprehensive understanding of the company's value and investment potential.
